@Bradninchfellow @BretDevereaux Indeed: “a time” could easily be several _centuries_ or more (see: slaves of African descent), but no coercion can last forever.

[I often wonder what the root causes of Chinese fear (other than centuries of pre-modern regional instability) is regarding those groups.]

@Bradninchfellow @BretDevereaux (That was not my intention but I understand that is how my comments may have been seen.)

1/2

subs.text:
@Bradninchfellow @BretDevereaux One must first agree with the premise of a question.

As you said earlier, nearly anything can be turned into an advantage long-term.

Since all diversity cannot be eliminated long-term, it seems prudent for societies to identify and mitigate the root causes of its problems.

2/2

subs.text: @FriedrichFiles @ThomasCatt1812 @amandalhu Units called ‘Heat Recovery Ventilators’ and ‘Energy Recovery Ventilators’ are available that allow ventilation with negligible increases in energy usage by transferring heat (#HRV) or heat+humidity (#ERV) between the stale and fresh air.
subs.rawText: @FriedrichFiles @ThomasCatt1812 @amandalhu Units called ‘Heat Recovery Ventilators’ and ‘Energy Recovery Ventilators’ are available that allow ventilation with negligible increases in energy usage by transferring heat (#HRV) or heat+humidity (#ERV) between the stale and fresh air.

subs.text:
@Bradninchfellow @BretDevereaux Something can be a short-term weakness while being a long-term strength.

If I am overwhelmed at work, I can hire an apprentice. I may be at a short-term disadvantage by having to devote time to training, but in the long-term this type of investment clearly is a winner.
subs.rawText:
@Bradninchfellow @BretDevereaux Something can be a short-term weakness while being a long-term strength.

If I am overwhelmed at work, I can hire an apprentice. I may be at a short-term disadvantage by having to devote time to training, but in the long-term this type of investment clearly is a winner.

subs.text:
@Bradninchfellow @BretDevereaux Political borders cannot survive forever unchanged.

If the ‘internal division’ from your hypothetical is problematic & persists for decades, perhaps the borders need to be updated.

Groups can disband, groups can coalesce. Groups can migrate.

Nature shows this on many scales.
subs.rawText:
@Bradninchfellow @BretDevereaux Political borders cannot survive forever unchanged.

Nature shows this on many scales.

subs.text:
@Bradninchfellow @BretDevereaux That there are only ‘two sides’ to any issue is a very dangerous mindset.

(that’s not an indictment of your comment, just a general statement)

Nature is probably the best example of ‘diversity’ in action (in terms of ‘evidence’), though.

Consider the Irish potato famine.
subs.rawText:

subs.text:
@Bradninchfellow @BretDevereaux Since diversity in any complex system cannot ever be completely and sustainably eliminated, the most logical course is to embrace (or at least accept) that eventually.

Any challenges can then be addressed head-on and based on their merits (rather than trying to assign blame).
subs.rawText:
@Bradninchfellow @BretDevereaux Since diversity in any complex system cannot ever be completely and sustainably eliminated, the most logical course is to embrace (or at least accept) that eventually.

Any challenges can then be addressed head-on and based on their merits (rather than trying to assign blame).

Blame neighboring nations for ones intractable problems?

subs.text: May 16

@chumak_iryna @britinvan @KiarKini @francis_scarr @KevinRothrock Previous major societal collapses happened in a different world, though.

Today, even peasants can receive near instantaneous news from the other side of the planet.

Young people in isolated and poor places (i.e. Nepal) have more options than ever.

Uncharted territory this is.
subs.rawText:

subs.text:
@chumak_iryna @KiarKini @britinvan @francis_scarr @KevinRothrock If Russia successfully breaks into pieces, the Basques might be inspired.

Perhaps the Scots.

Perhaps the Kurds.

Andalusians. Balochs. Hmong. Palestinians. Rohingya. Uyghurs. Zulu.

There will be an _enormous_ amount of elite pressure (worldwide) to prevent that idea spreading.

@chumak_iryna @britinvan @KiarKini @francis_scarr @KevinRothrock I agree.

Outside of large cities, though, what if they didn’t _have_ to fight? If there is no one to fight against?

If your town is a minority in a political subdivision, and the government collapses, then your town is a majority in your town.

Perhaps your town becomes Monaco?

subs.text:
@johngineer @TrentTelenko Vendors have an incentive to over-state capabilities.

Militaries have an incentive to under-state capabilities (or to over-state for deterrence, a-la Reagan’s ‘SDI’/‘Star Wars’ or DPRK and Russia).

🤷

Actual field performance depends on many factors, and is likely classified.

subs.text:
@moscow_english @sentdefender It’s not _that_ small of an area.
  They’d all fit in a large-sized harbor.

The Black Sea is has a _surface area_ of 168,500 mi², equal area to a square 410 miles on each side.

(i.e. 436,400 km², equal area to a square 660 km on each side)

Also, submarines operate in 3D space.

subs.text: @Bear_Faced @ClavdiaMinor @sentdefender Yes, but if poor maintenance practices had not lead to that fire (oily bilge water causing self-ignition of chemical oxygen generator cartridges, if I recall correctly), those crew members could have survived until rescued.

subs.text: May 13

@Bill_Abely @brandonazheng @Noahpinion “They” has long been a default when it is not known what pronoun to use; e.g.:

A: “Someone broke into my car last night.”
B: “That’s horrible! Did they steal anything valuable?”
A: “No, that almost makes it worse. They broke two windows for nothing!”
B: “I hope they get caught!”
subs.rawText:

A: “No, that almost makes it worse. They broke two windows for nothing!”

subs.text:
@nicholrr @TrentTelenko DD-459 was sunk at Guadalcanal.

DD-724 was built two years later, and was also a former USS Laffey.

DD-724 is the museum ship in SC next to the former USS Yorktown*.

(That is CV-10, which itself was a replacement for an earlier ‘Yorktown’, CV-5, that sank at Midway).

@lithohedron @boondaburrah @errantambition @Foone They’re still used by expensive lab hardware such as oscilloscopes, and also in some military equipment.

If you need to quickly move a 50kB file between two air-gapped systems from different vendors, these can be faster, more secure,& lower-overhead than using a USB flash drive.
